text: So I'm going to start with a very annoying show of hands but I'm assuming we're at KCDUK So I'll ask everyone to put their hands up and then put your hands hands up come on Put your hands down if you're not running Kubernetes Okay Hands down if you're not using microservice architecture or service oriented architecture Hands down if you're not using GraphQL All right This is a perfect room I love it So this talk is a secret talk about GraphQL but focused on microservice architectures running on containers with Kubernetes And this is my mission today Has anyone ever deployed a microservice as a single column in a database Yeah maybe I'm the same But I want to convince you that this is not the worst idea and actually makes a lot of sense as we adopt more and more microservices Now I'm not going to actually show your hands but microservice adoption is very Everyone in Cloud Native is at some point in that journey to be in microservice or service oriented architecture To the point now where we look at companies like Google Meta Netflix I could just sit and list companies for the next 30 minutes and the talk would be done But they're at a stage now where they have not just thousands but tens of thousands of microservices And there becomes a lot of challenges in scaling microservices even at dozens right So this is applicable to anyone even early in that journey where they just have 10 microservices or 30 microservices If you don't know who I am my name is David Flanagan I'm from Glasgow the better city Wrong room I have the Rockwood Academy This started off as a YouTube channel where I just make videos on Cloud Native technologies I want to make Kubernetes accessible to everybody So if you've ever struggled with microservices Kubernetes or any of the challenges and there are many of them that come with this approach Please check out the YouTube channel and more importantly check out the website We're now at a stage where there's over 500 videos which is over 650 hours of content on the Cloud Native landscape I'm not going to show the landscape document We've all seen it It's super scary It grows exponentially at a rate none of us can learn right You're not expected to learn all of this stuff I just want to make it easier for you to learn the stuff that you need to learn So please check it out Now we're going to start with a very contrived example for BitHub where we have issues comments and projects We all use GitHub We know it's there We all use GitHub issues We possibly contribute to open source And you may see some sort of ERG like this some sort of entity relationship where our issues can have comments they can be part of a project And we never get this right the first time At some point we need to evolve our Our requirements change Our project is evolving And all of a sudden we're like all right okay What if our project needs a status What if our project manager or product owner whatever we call it these days has decided well our issues have a state Why doesn't our project have a state Maybe our project should be on time Maybe it should be delayed Maybe it is canceled Whatever we want At some point we need to add a new column Now with microservice architectures we could add a new It wouldn't be that hard Who enjoys schema migrations Nobody All right Well of course not right There's a whole bunch of heuristics There are rules that we need to follow in order to do a safe schema migration We never rename columns We only add columns We only do this Everything should have a default value Nobody knows all these rules because technology evolves and the rules change So well a naive approach could be and I'm not saying a wrong approach right If anyone's sitting here going I've got a microservice and I've done this that's okay I just want to show you that it's potentially a different route So this is okay But there are challenges with a SQL migration Not everybody knows this the first time In fact I've been doing this for over 20 years and I still make mistakes with SQL all the time and locking semantics But if you want to do a safe zero time migration or modification to any table within a SQL database and I'm using the two biggest ones here which are MySQL and then you have to make sure that the column is only ever added at the end of the And you may not even be aware that you can change that but you can You have to make sure there's always a default value even if it's null which may or may not make sense depending on the column that you're adding to your table And you have to make sure there are no constraints or rules on the values for those columns And that is obviously quite difficult to do if you want to have a database abstraction or at least some sort of validity concerns encoded at the database layer which is generally quite a good thing to do So as long as you follow these rules you can add a column and you will have a zero downtime migration and you can all go to the pub and enjoy the rest of your day But unfortunately that is a very simple change of adding a column And schema migrations can actually be quite difficult Sometimes we do need to rename a column or we want to change the column type Maybe we started off with a very naive integer but we actually need float based values And this is where we start adding on all these rules again Okay well we only ever add columns so we're not going to rename or change the column type We're going to add a new column we're going to migrate all the data and it just becomes a lot of work And then this becomes tribal knowledge within your team about why we have a state column and a status column and a status two column We've all been there So schema migrations are just hard across the especially when we constrain ourselves to doing it within a table that already exists which is why we have all of this tooling And I'm only listing four here but I could easily have made this a 30 plus listing of tools And I've tried to satisfy the old Java developers with Liquibase and Flyway but if you're cloud native in that case hopefully you're writing in Actually you should just migrate to Rust right now But hopefully you're using Schema Schema Hero which is written in It's an operator that runs your Kubernetes cluster and manages your database tables for you Or at the very least you're using something like Atlas which is a HCL Terraform like approach to doing schema migrations These are cool tools but they don't remove the problem They mask the problem They give us tooling to make sure that we don't make the that may be ingrained in tribal knowledge within our teams and our organization So I propose to you what if instead of doing a relatively simple ish add column on what if we spun up a new service And a service could just be responsible for a single column which is the state of a project but it does have foreign key constraints to a degree where we reference the project and the project service We have no schema migrations We don't have to worry about downtime Actually you get a really nice benefit with this approach And if I decide to state this is the wrong name for the column I can spin up a new service copy the data spin it over zero downtime across the board And I want to show you how this is possible using the tooling that we have available to us today So I asked you all to show your and I think only two hands are up for GraphQL So I am going to cover a few of the basics of how GraphQL works But specifically what I want to show you is that when we're doing microservice architectures there really is the right way in my opinion to do read models And I think GraphQL is a really good fit for this Now if any of you out there are going well what about gRPC and what about REST and API gateways and all that stuff Some of this is possible with those technologies And if you want to go into that in more detail ask questions at the end or just find me at the after party I'm happy to sit and talk about the flaws with all of these approaches And this approach is not without its flaws but I'm going to try and make them very transparent as well as we go So GraphQL Federation works and we have some sort of client query that comes to our The router is our API gateway for GraphQL And that can do some very very sophisticated things to the point where we have something called entity resolution which knows if we are looking for a project to go to the project microservice We have something called a key that I'll go into in more detail shortly But this says if you ever need to find a project in any query you find it at this service here We then have our issue service and our status service which is actually extending our project entity to provide new functionality as we expand our rules All of this happens behind the scene before eventually it spits out a response which comes to whoever called the So a lot of this is magic that just happens behind the scene by the GraphQL router that you never really need to worry about But of course you do need to worry about it because there's a whole bunch of trade offs and performance optimization things that you need to know to make sure that you don't DDoS yourself as your clients are coming in GraphQL looks like this It's a really cool language where we can say I want to get all the issue details The name here is completely irrelevant because the queries are whatever I name them so I know how to parse the response when it comes back But the entities within are important and are referenced and handled by the router Specifically here we have a read model for issues which actually has a nested entity resolution for comments This is weird for people that are not familiar with GraphQL But because the GraphQL router understands the relationships of every entity within the system we can nest these as deep as we want Some of you will be going that sounds quite scary and it is But again we have rules and regulations constraints that we can put in place to make sure we don't denial of service attack ourselves So here the router knows that we have issues and the comments are related to issues and we can fetch them if we have enough information  Then we have project details Right now our project only has a name and a but if we do this right and we deploy our new service that extends the entity with our status we can do something like this where we can say okay I want to get the project but I also want to get its issues and its comments Again this query is not something that you as a back end developer and I'm making some that if we have these entities available they can be resolved and the client gets to make up whatever shape they need to satisfy their application the front end application There's a lot of power and These are things that we don't have with REST or gRPC where there's a fixed view of the world that has to be with the front end and the back end GraphQL allows us to have this facade where we say you can query whatever you want and it does it for us Now this works because GraphQL has something called directives These directives are for example a key This is how entity resolution works When we define a type of project we see that it is keyed on an ID Really simple right If I want to find a project I just need to know its ID What's really cool about GraphQL is that this supports composite keys as well If I want to fetch an issue comment I may have to know the issue and the comment ID to fetch that one particular thing Composite keys are well supported well documented I'm just not showing an example for Brevi Now we also have requires When we do entity extension we can't just say we can extend a project without knowing the If we're going to extend some entity we need to know its Again this supports composite keys We can handle all of that with composite key directives If we want to extend the project type we can have a microservice that says we extend the project type as long as we have the external identifier This external directive is another directive that we're not going into in a lot of It just says this is owned by another service If we have it we can use our service to provide new information for that service In this case we have a status and an updated data This is a status with updated data with everything Now GraphQL queries can be very complex They can be deeply nested where issue back up we can have a project that requests all of the issues attached to the project That issue can then request comments That comment can then also sub select its issue again going back up the tree You can imagine that issues and comments can indefinitely recurse where issues ask for comments comments ask for issues because we don't control the query on the front end While we can protect that at the router and I'll talk about that towards the end we can also use the provides directive for hot paths If we know that whenever someone requests comments they request the user that did the comment as well you can see that we can actually satisfy that without going the extra hop to the extra service because we have a shared cache where the comment service is allowed to fetch read only user information Now I know this can get really complex GraphQL can be very complex but with that complexity comes the ability to and hopefully make your release a little bit easier Now I don't think these are moving parts that you aren't already dealing with Now if you have a microservice architecture we have this kind of cloud native promise that everyone gets you have to sign the agreement before you can say you're cloud native whereas we are going to write super simple services that are less than X number lines of Who wants to define what a microservice is Anyone We can No one has ever said what micro is micro enough However we're promised that our lives will be simpler Now that complexity doesn't disappear as we all know If you have more than one service the complexity from each individual service does disappear but is pushed down to the platform layer or the infrastructure layer We have to handle service discovery retry logic we have to have rate limiting we have circuit breakers we have service meshes we have RBAC and authentication and authorization rules that have to be ubiquitous across every single microservice It's not a free lunch GraphQL Federation is the We do simplify the lives for our clients or mobile applications on our websites on the front end but the complexity is just pushed down It's not removed I just want to make that clear as that you are taking on an operational burden to some degree and most of this is handled by the router via the query planning and the entity resolution What's really nice about the depending on the router that you adopt and there's a few different open source options you can use is that when the query comes in it will try to work out all of the different entities It will then cache or query plan as much of that as I'm always trying to think of this as a real example If we're at GitHub and we query all of the comments on an issue and all of the users service with the 50 different users that make the query are left the comments no We want to send one request where we have 50 IDs and say give me all these users back A router will handle all of this for you kind of for free Now what's nice about this is that the router can be independently scaled You can deploy as many routers as you need You can handle the independently at a service level as well You can have your user cache You can have your comments cache You can have a cache that satisfies all of them or at least different boundaries that you define It's really up to you if you want to do this at the router level the entity level or to some degree you can even do it at a column level Again if you have hot paths that you as a platform engineer or backend developer can identify you build the cache that Again the frontend doesn't really have to worry about it What's really nice about this is that we can determine where we're happy to have our fault boundaries Nobody in here is sitting and saying okay it's just not going to You have to where you're going to allow those faults There may be paths within your GraphQL query It's okay for this to fail because our application can still be used It can still be successful We're willing to take a hit on this certain query path and that can all be encoded in GraphQL via the router as well All right Let's skip this one The other very nice approach to this is that something we lose out on a lot again I'm making assumptions about us being mostly backend developers within a room maybe writing in Go or Rust is that there's this whole world out here of TypeScript and Node and JavaScript and Bun and Deno and Vite et cetera that are deploying to Vercel or Netlify or Cloudflare They're getting all of this pre computed to a certain degree that is edge scalable GraphQL makes this possible too because you can write your GraphQL resolvers in these languages I'm going to try and show off some of how the Rockwood Academy works because I have over engineered this for my own craziness I guess to a certain degree Everything is deployed on Cloudflare which means it's in over 300 different edge locations around the If you're in Australia or if you're in Argentina and you across the Rockwood Academy website my goal is to have that response be less than 50 milliseconds GraphQL makes this possible as well via leveraging CDN caching as well Now a lot of this requires sophisticated CI CD I'm just hoping that we've all got this controlled in 2025 and we're not also running whatever random deployment mechanism saying that we don't deploy on Fridays or anything like that because if you have a microservice architecture and your deployments aren't automated you're probably sitting here in a world of hurt You've probably got your laptop on your knee because you're waiting for that next Slack message to make your system is down Use GitHub Actions use Jenkins use Dagger I don't know what you're but just make sure all your deployments are automated and hopefully happen multiple times per day Because in a microservice architecture if you don't have the basics down adopting something like GraphQL Federation will make you sit here thinking oh that guy said I should be doing this so I'm going to do it and then you don't get any sleep for the next six months You really do need to have the basics and the primitives sorted and automation is a very good first step for that as We also need to be able to control the scaling of these services If you're going to extend an existing entity with a brand new service make sure you do have the ability to scale that independently I've got a 10 minute warning so I'm going to try and speed up because I did want to show you how this works for real life but there are tradeoffs I will make these slides available Again it just comes down to making sure that you have automation as a bare metal fundamental to everything that you're doing Where things get tricky is that autonomy within a microservice architecture is quite difficult If you deploy the project service and you're responsible for that and someone decides they want to use GraphQL via GraphQL directives you can actually make up your own directives You can have ownership You can have SLAs You can have SLIs SLOs whatever You can embed that all into the GraphQL IDL It just means anyone who queries your graph or has access to the schema STL can get all of that information right away Again you can automate this with runbooks You can have a runbook that pulls down the You can say I have a problem with this service and it tells you who you're responsible for and who you need to go speak to on Slack Everything that is flexible as well even if it's not without its trade offs Right Let's show you how this works I am using something called Cosmo It is a GraphQL router It's written in Go which means it's cloud native by default It's really hard to see this now I have a whole bunch of The Rocket Academy think of it like YouTube It's my own personal YouTube to deliver educational content to I have videos If I scroll down hopefully videos is on the first page We have a video service that has the title of the video It has the length of the and it has a URL to get that video via M3U8 which is the playlist file The video service is really simple As I add new functionality to that I'm doing it via entity extension in GraphQL We have episodes which is a video that is part of a show This is just a very simple service where it has a video ID and a show ID and some sort of episode code You can create something like cloud native compass or rocket live and say give me episode four and it will handle that resolution for you We have emoji reactions You can go to the RockCode Academy website If you're logged in and you're watching a you can sum it up you can heart it you can add a beard emoji whatever you want This is a microservice that just has a video ID a user ID and some sort of emoji unit code Where I started to push this maybe to my own detriment but also in the name of education and fun I thought okay a show has hosts I'm sure every sane person in this room who wants to add hosts to a would just go to the show service and add a new column of hosts or hosts I decided to do a distributed join with a new microservice where I have the show host service which all it has is a show ID and a person ID and this now becomes the We also have a guest service We actually have a it's more agnostic than that but you can think of it as a guest so if If I run this again for instance I don't have caching set up My apologies I would not run these queries again against the microservices I am running out of time so I'm going to move forward I think what the really cool thing about this is is that GraphQL is a fantastic technology Federation is very sophisticated and I think it's the ideal path for all read models within a microservice architecture to the point where I think GraphQL can actually become an IDL for all of our microservices This is one of the things that we struggle with and we're starting to lean into tools like Backstage and other platform engineering tools that give us this pane of to understand our But if we can define it all in GraphQL and we can add our own directives we can add our SLOs our maintainers everything this becomes a really important infrastructure pattern that makes platform engineering a lot easier as we grow our microservice architecture Federation makes it so that instead of using SQL migrations and modifying existing code we can add new code The really cool side effect here is if we make a maybe we decided to add a project status maybe we got the column type wrong maybe we got the
